column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column13: The Tax Policy applies to all functions of NAB, including employees, contractors and agents. The Tax Policy is reviewed regularly, and the NAB Board approves any changes. For the Tax Policy, Tax Risk is defined as an unexpected adverse financial or reputational consequence arising to NAB from adopting a position or taking an action inconsistent with NAB's key tax principles.
column20: Tax Policy, tax risk, tax principle

column7: NAB undertakes international related party dealings between its operations in Australia and its offshore branches and subsidiaries. All transactions are conducted consistently with the arm's length standard in line with the Tax Policy.

column7: NAB's direct energy consumption in 2023 was 89,331 GJ.

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization
column7: NAB's indirect energy consumption in 2023 was 311,806 GJ.
NAB supports commercial real estate owners via direct financing to upgrade their assets to improve energy efficiency.

column13: In 2014, NAB's United Kingdom-based operations became subject to the Energy Savings Opportunities Scheme (ESOS), introduced by the United Kingdom ESOS Regulations 2014. The ESOS requires mandatory energy assessments (audits) of organisation buildings and transport every four years. The Group's London Branch completed its ESOS energy efficiency assessment in 2023 to prepare for its ESOS submission.
column20: Energy Savings Opportunities Scheme, energy assessment, ESOS regulation

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column7: The Commercial Building Disclosure Program is managed by the Australian Government Department of Climate Change, Energy, the Environment and Water. It aims to improve the energy efficiency of Australia's largest office buildings by requiring energy efficiency information, including emissions data, to be provided where commercial office space of 1,000 square metres or more is offered for sale or lease.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column13: NAB participated in a UNEP FI project designed to support financial institutions in understanding the role of nature scenarios (a similar concept to climate scenarios). Such scenarios can help decision-makers by establishing an agreed definition of the future status of nature, e.g., how soil quality might change and what risks and opportunities may arise for the productivity of agribusinesses as a result.
column20: UNEP FI, financial institution, nature scenario

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: In 2023, NAB supported the continued development of the Natural Capital Measurement Catalogue project, which included the launch of an open-access web-based interface where users can select metrics and methods for the measurement of natural capital assets, flows of services or benefits, and organisational impacts or dependencies on nature.
column20: Natural Capital Measurement Catalogue, natural capital, organisational impact

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: During 2023, NAB undertook a preliminary assessment of its nature-related impacts and dependencies. The analysis identified that the most material customer-related impacts on nature are associated with the agriculture, construction, manufacturing, mining, energy and utilities industries, and transport and storage. The highest impacts on nature across the portfolio relate to land and water use, GHG emissions and waste production.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: NAB is developing the capability to geo-locate agricultural customers' assets more accurately through its FarmID database (under development). While initially intended to support the identification of exposure to climate-related hazards, the analytical infrastructure will provide the foundation for understanding a range of nature-related risks in the future.

The NAB Foundation supports primary research by Greening Australia and WWF on the efficacy of nature-based solutions for enhancing environmental resilience to fire through vegetation configuration. This multi-year project is moving to the implementation phase, which includes establishing a demonstration site.

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations

column7: NAB's scope 1 emissions in 2023 was 7,590 tCO2e.
NAB's scope 2 emissions in 2023 was 57,320 tCO2e.
NAB's scope 3 emissions in 2023 was 54,078 tCO2e.

column13: NAB is partnering with cleantech start-up Greener to support the decarbonisation efforts of small business customers. Partly funded by NAB Ventures, the free 'Greener for Business' platform provides guidance, sustainability insights and a step-by-step climate action plan to help small business users understand and take practical steps aimed at reducing their carbon footprint while also giving users access to exclusive sustainability offers from leading suppliers to help save on costs.

column8: Climate Data Science and Engineering team
column13: NAB has established a dedicated Climate Data Science and Engineering team. The team is responsible for developing the knowledge and skills required to understand and assess the impacts of climate change on NAB and its customers. The team has been working closely with academic, government and commercial stakeholders to accelerate the work and ensure the consistent application of science across the bank.
column20: Climate Data Science and Engineering team, climate change impact, science

column13: In 2023, NAB completed its work to assess the transition maturity for 100 of its largest GHG-emitting customers using a Transition Maturity Diagnostic (the "Diagnostic"), building on the work commenced in 2021. The diagnostic was designed concerning global frameworks such as the Transition Pathway Initiative, a global asset owners' initiative that assesses companies' preparedness to transition to a low-carbon economy.
column20: Transition Maturity Diagnostic, global framework, low-carbon economy

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
column13: NAB worked with Melbourne Business School to co-design, co-develop, and co-deliver five climate training programs for NAB colleagues across 2023 and 2024. The training comprises a climate foundations eLearn and webinar series available to all NAB colleagues and training programs for relevant bankers focusing on key sectors, including residential and commercial real estate, agribusiness and transport.
column20: Climate training program, Melbourne Business School, eLearn
